data.title: Automatically switch to next line on comment
data.body:
It would be great to automatically switch the cursor to next line on commenting a line via shortcut.
This means that you can press the comment-shortcut multiple times and all the lines would be commented out. Webstorm already supports this feature and i think it would be great if vscode can also support.

data.title: CPU usage even when idle (due to cursor rendering)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

VS Code uses 13% CPU when focused and idle, draining battery. This is likely due to the blinking cursor rendering. I think CPU usage when focused-and-idle could ideally be near-0%.

To reproduce (this works with an empty settings file and all plugins disabled):

1. Close all VS Code windows.
2. Open a new window (File -> New Window). It will show the Welcome page.
3. Open a new tab with an empty untitled file (File -> New Tab). The cursor is blinking.
4. You should see VS Code consuming a non-negligible amount of CPU -- 13% on my 13" MacBook Pro.
5. Cmd+Tab into some other application. Now the cursor isn't visible anymore.
6. You should see VS Code consuming virtually no CPU.

I recorded a Timeline in the Developer Tools, and a cursory look suggests that the CPU activity comes from rendering the blinking cursor every 500ms.

Other macOS applications like Chrome or TextEdit show a blinking cursor without consuming much CPU, so I think this could surely be optimized away.

data.title: Using "auto" or "inspector" protocol skips breakpoints in mocha test
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In launch.json change protocol from "legacy" to "auto" or "inspector" for mocha test.
2. Set a breakpoint within a test case
3. Start the debugger

I have the following launch configuration:

            "type": "node",
            "protocol": "legacy",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "test - util.wait",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/util.wait/node_modules/.bin/_mocha",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": ["test/tests.js"],
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/util.wait"

If I use "legacy" I can set a breakpoint and debug into a test case in mocha without issue.  If I use "auto" or "inspector" the breakpoint is skipped.  The tests will still run, but I cannot step debug into it.  I set this to "auto" as a test per the transitioning blog notes link below.

https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_10#_node2-transitioning

I realize this is a transition, but it said to report anything that didn't work.

data.title: Find all references shows bogus results
data.body:
1. Do a find all references a couple of times
2. Notice that some results appear to highlight an empty line
3. After closing and reopening find all references widget result are no longer bogus

Notice that I only started seeing this today, it was working fine last week

Just try doing find all references a couple of times on the MenuRegistry [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/platform/actions/common/actions.ts#L81)

![screen shot 2017-03-20 at 16 56 38](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/24108585/4dd5c5ba-0d8e-11e7-8ecb-bd8f8c5c6e0b.png)

data.title: Keyboard shortcuts not updated when keyboard language is changed

- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

1. Init VSCode and Change the keyboard language.
2. Use a keyboard shortcut that is different from the previous language.

For example I have a Portuguese keyboard and an English one. If I change the keyboard language from Portuguese to English `CMD + /` doesn't work to comment code until I restart VSCode.

data.title: Terminal: problems when pasting multiple lines of text
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (207686d256dafb78b247357ad8b96a95218a22a5, 2017-03-17T08:14:15.805Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15048
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|typings-installer|benjaminromano|0.2.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.7|
|theme-dracula|dracula-theme|1.8.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.8.1|
|vscode-great-icons|emmanuelbeziat|1.1.44|
|Theme-azure|gerane|0.0.2|
|docthis|joelday|0.4.3|
|theme-material-theme|jprestidge|1.0.1|
|vs-color-picker|lihui|0.6.0|
|Theme-MaterialKit|ms-vscode|0.1.1|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.7.0|
|view-in-browser|qinjia|0.0.5|
|java|redhat|0.0.13|
|ActiveFileInStatusBar|RoscoP|1.0.2|
|vscode-hexdump|slevesque|1.2.1|
|eval|Stormspirit|0.0.6|
|omnipascal|Wosi|0.13.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a terminal and run "bash"
2. run `nano foo` with a text file containing some lines of text
3. press ctrl+v (or right-click) to paste some lines of text

What's expected:

The text should be appended before the cursor, and the existing text should be there after the cursor.

What happens:

Existing text disappears, and it seems some extra newlines are added when pasting text.

*Note:* there is no such problem when doing the exact same steps with CMD.exe

This happens on insider builds, no idea if it happens with standard builds as well.

data.title: [RFC] Show Problems Panel API
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: OSX 10.12.3

Currently, we can always show `OUTPUT`, `DEBUG CONSOLE` and `TERMINAL` panel using APIs.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6234553/24105750/d4232298-0dc0-11e7-97fa-6404676c74d2.png)

But for the `PROBLEMS` panel, we can only display it manually.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6234553/24105826/1492b74e-0dc1-11e7-8a99-1fa891667d29.png)

So is there any existing API to show the `PROBLEMS` panel, or maybe VSCode can support it in the future?

data.title: Inconsistent coloring of JSON formatted content files in default editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.11.0-insider (1.11.0-insider) 05f19eec2042555ca04e5f014befa95248a65fe9
- OS Version: 10.12.3 (16D32) (mac OS Sierra)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open `launch.json` file in VSCode
2. open users settings `settings.json` in VSCode
3. Use default dark VS theme

Sorry if that is reported already but I couldn't find using expected keywords.

I've noticed that the syntex rendering is inconsistent between files in recent versions of VSCode.
Here are the screenshots of JSON formatted files, both with extra comments and both in VSCode launched without extensions enabled:

- `launch.json`:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14539/24099100/fbe97e7e-0d6d-11e7-8b90-feedad3c8729.png)


- `settings.json`

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14539/24099126/117788d0-0d6e-11e7-8629-3dfa527cbeae.png)


What's more interesting. If I copy and paste content of `launch.json` into the panel of users settings the rendering will be OK, so that seems to be not related to the content of JSON file:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14539/24099188/4289b434-0d6e-11e7-9e0e-5e56f41ee427.png)

Thanks!

data.title: Duplication of file with a number as filename
data.body:
In the file explorer side bar, use cmd-C and cmd-V to duplicate a file with the name given by a number will yield a new file with the name increased by 1, other than appending ".1" on the original filename as expected. 
For example: duplication of "24.sh" gives "25.sh" rather than "24.1.sh".

data.title: Delay between key-press and rendering
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise, SP1 **and** Windows 10 Home

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a large file (for instance a 20k+ lines python file).
2. Press PageDown and watch the delay between each key-press and when the rendering happens. It's hard to measure, but I'd say the delay is at least 100 ms, probably more.
3. Load the same file in Notepad++ and do the same experiment. You'll see that there is no noticeable delay between the key-press and the rendering.

This seems to happen on all extensions all the time, it seems fundamental. My colleague has it too, and the commenter on my StackOverflow question as well; I believe everyone has it. It's just that a lot of developers are fine with it.

I've seen no suggestions to circumvent this delay in the question I posted on [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/39648612/visual-studio-code-rendering-delay). This is a nuisance and really a showstopper for me - I can't use an editor with too slow rendering - which is a shame as I think Visual Studio Code seems like an otherwise awesome tool.

data.title: "Open with code" context menu option on folder should open a new instance of VS Code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

If no instance of VS Code is running the option works as expected.
If there's an already running instance of VS Code then nothing happens.

Is there a way to make it happen even when there's an already running instance?
I'd say this capability should be implemented out-of-the-box.

P. S. As a side note: it would be great if the devs' experience in simultaneously working with multiple projects will improve. This subject is just one step.

data.title: Integrated Terminal cmd.exe does not support UNC path
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:02:52.799Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\\WINDOWS\\\system32\\\cmd.exe"
2. Open a file in VS Code stored on file share
3. cmd.exe reports that "UNC paths are not supported.  Defaulting to Windows directory."

How do I do a @pushd %~dp0 for this cmd.exe terminal session?
It needs to @popd when terminal is closed too.
